page.title: 07WEATHER WELLS-NEXT-THE-SEA
page.content: The area benefits greatly from the modifying influence of the sea and the ser of frosts helps in growing barley and kale for seed. It is however exposed to all winds from a northerly direction. High pressure located over the British Isles brings problems in both summer and winter. During summer sunshine winds come off the the cool North Sea often bringing a cold mist;known locally as a 'fret', onto the crowded sandy beaches. In winter the winds are drawn from Europe across the comparatively warm North Sea bringing heavy falls of snow or are bitingly cold. Low rainfall amounts- and- sunshine hours excess of 4 hours daily on average are two factors extremely important to both the tourist and agricultural industries.
